The treatise says:

That is to say, based on the Mahayana, the World-Honored Buddhas have ten kinds of supreme and excellent teachings. That is to say, a bodhisattva must first understand well the causes of dharmas before he can attain skillfulness in conditioned arising.

In order to clarify how one proceeds to great enlightenment through this [path], the sequential methods and necessary causes are further revealed.

It means that bodhisattvas must first attain skill in the causes, and only then should they attain skill in dependent origination, knowing that from this cause there is that effect, and further knowing that that effect must arise from this cause. By explaining this, one abandons causelessness and unequal causation.
Next, one should understand the characteristics of all dharmas produced from conditions, in order to avoid the extremes of superimposition and denial.

Because one superimposes the existence of what is causeless, it is called superimposition. Because one denies the existence of what has a cause, it is called denial. Thus, superimposition and denial are both called extremes. This means falling into error, because when these two occur, one loses the middle way.

Because of repeatedly cultivating true contemplation, one skillfully avoids these two extremes. With regard to the imagined, there is only superimposition and no denial, because it does not exist at all. One can only deny what exists.
With regard to the dependent, there is no superimposition, because it has a substance. One can only superimpose what does not exist.
Nor is there denial, because it exists only as a false appearance.
With regard to the perfected, there is no superimposition, because it really exists. There is only denial.

For this reason, or else, one who is able to skillfully avoid the two extreme errors of superimposition and denial with regard to this dependent nature is one who superimposes the really non-existent imagined nature on the dependent nature and denies the really existent perfected nature.
